title: How to Memorize the Unit Circle

steps.title: Learn that ASAP means â€œAll, Subtract, Add, Prime.â€
steps.content: Learn that ASAP means â€œAll, Subtract, Add, Prime.â€ You can remember it using the acronym â€œA Student Always Practices.â€ This handy acronym can help you remember how to find the radians for each angle. Unfortunately, the radians arenâ€™t the same across the different quadrants, though they do share common denominators. Thatâ€™s because the radians will be in order from 0 to 2ğ›‘. steps.title: See that the x-axis is not a fraction.
steps.content: See that the x-axis is not a fraction. Itâ€™s helpful to think of your x-axis as a whole number. The positive side is 0 or 2ğ›‘, while the negative side is 1ğ›‘. That is because the top part of the circle by itself measures 1ğ›‘, plus the bottom part of the circle by itself also measures 1ğ›‘. The negative side of the x-axis is halfway around your circle, while the positive side is both the start and finish of the circle. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Notice that the y-axis has a denominator of 2.
steps.content: Notice that the y-axis has a denominator of 2. Since the entire top half of the circle measures 1ğ›‘, it makes sense that the measurement of the positive y-axis would be 1ğ›‘/2. [4] X Research source Thatâ€™s because the y-axis splits the top part of the circle in half. Similarly, the bottom part of the circle is 3ğ›‘/2 because the negative y-axis is splitting it in half. If you have trouble remembering that the negative y-axis is 3ğ›‘/2, you can use the addition addition trick for finding the third quadrant radians.

steps.title: Recognize each quadrant shares the denominators 6, 4, and 3.
steps.content: Recognize each quadrant shares the denominators 6, 4, and 3. This makes it easier to memorize the radians. The number 3 is always close to the y-axis, while the number 6 is always close to the x-axis. That might seem tricky, but it helps to remember that the smaller numbers are on top or bottom, while the larger numbers are side to side. [5] X Research source Quadrant 1 denominators look like this: 6, 4, 3 Quadrant 2 denominators look like this: 3, 4, 6 Quadrant 3 denominators are in this order: 6, 4, 3 Quadrant 4 denominators are in this order: 3, 4, 6

steps.title: Learn all the radians for the first quadrant angles.
steps.content: Learn a ll the radians for the first quadrant angles. [6] X Expert Source Jake Adams Academic Tutor & Test Prep Specialist Expert Interview. 20 May 2020. A radian is the measure of an angle. Each measurement will be in pi, since a circleâ€™s circumference is based on pi. The radians of a unit circle go from 0 to 2ğ›‘. Most angles on your circle will be a fraction of pi. Here are the radian measurements for the first quadrant: [7] X Research source 0 degree angles have a measurement of 0. A 30 degree angle has a measurement of ğ›‘/6. A 45 degree angle has a measurement of ğ›‘/4. A 60 degree angle has a measurement of ğ›‘/3. A 90 degree angle has a measurement of ğ›‘/2.

steps.title: S
steps.content: S ubtract 1 from the denominator to get the numerator for the second quadrant. Knowing the pattern for the denominators as presented above allows you to easily remember all of the angle measurements. In the second quadrant, we know the denominators go 3, 4, and 6. Simply subtract 1 digit from the denominator, and you now have the numerator value in the fraction. Just remember to add ğ›‘ to the numerator. Here are the radians for the second quadrant angles: [8] X Research source A 120 degree angle has a radian of 2ğ›‘/3. A 135 degree angle has a radian of 3ğ›‘/4. A 150 degree angle has a radian of 5ğ›‘/6. A 180 degree angle has a radian of ğ›‘. (Remember, this is your negative x-axis, which was discussed above.)

steps.title: A
steps.content: A dd 1 to the denominator to get the numerator for the third quadrant. Remember that the denominators in the third quadrant go 6, 4, and 3. The numerator for each radian measurement will be the denominator + 1, multiplied by ğ›‘. Here are the radian measurements for the third quadrant: [9] X Research source A 210 degree angle has a radian of 7ğ›‘/6. A 225 degree angle has a radian of 5ğ›‘/4. A 240 degree angle has a radian of 4ğ›‘/3. A 270 degree angle has a measurement of 3ğ›‘/2, since this is your negative y-axis. Luckily, your quadrant trick works for this angle!

steps.title: Use the prime numbers to get the numerators for the fourth quadrant.
steps.content: Use the p rime numbers to get the numerators for the fourth quadrant. The trick for finding the numerators in the radian measurements for the fourth quadrant comes down to remembering the prime numbers 3, 5, 7, and 11. Here are the angle measurements: [10] X Research source The 270 degree angle uses 3 to get a radian of 3ğ›‘/2. A 300 degree angle has 5 in the denominator, for 5ğ›‘/3. A 315 degree angle has 7 in the denominator, for 7ğ›‘/4. A 330 degree angle has 11 in the denominator, for 11ğ›‘/6. Finally, the circle ends on a 360 degree angle, which has a radian of 2ğ›‘. (Remember, this is your positive x-axis, as explained above.)

steps.title: Spread your left palm so your thumb and pinky make a right angle.
steps.content: Spread your left palm so your thumb and pinky make a right angle. The first quadrant is the top, right side of the circle. Itâ€™s the part of the circle where both the x-coordinate and the y-coordinate are positive. [11] X Research source [12] X Research source

steps.title: Imagine that each finger represents an angle in the first quadrant.
steps.content: Imagine that each finger represents an angle in the first quadrant. As you move into other quadrants, the angle measurement will change. However, the coordinates for sine and cosine will be the same integer, though they may shift from positive to negative. That means you can use your left hand trick to find the coordinates in any quadrant! Hereâ€™s how to label your fingers: [13] X Research source Use your pinky to represent a 0 degree angle. The 0 degree angle falls on your x-axis. Itâ€™s the starting point of your circle, which is why itâ€™s 0. Your ring finger represents a 30 degree angle. Let your middle finger represent a 45 degree angle. Your index finger represents a 60 degree angle. Make your thumb represent the 90 degree angle.

steps.title: Find the cosine coordinate of an angle by counting the fingers to the left.
steps.content: Find the cosine coordinate of an angle by counting the fingers to the left. Put down the finger youâ€™re using to represent the angle you want to find the cosine for. Count the number of fingers to the left of the finger that represents your angle. Then, take the square root of this number and divide it by 2 to find your coordinates. [14] X Research source For example, if you were finding the coordinates for a 30 degree angle, youâ€™d put down your ring finger. To the left of that finger, you have your thumb, index finger, and middle finger, which means 3 fingers. This means the cosine coordinate is 3 2 {\displaystyle {\frac {\sqrt {3}}{2}}} . This is your final answer since you can't simplify the fraction any further. If you were getting the cosine for a 0 degree angle, youâ€™d put down your pinkie and count 4 fingers to the left. Your equation is 4 2 {\displaystyle {\frac {\sqrt {4}}{2}}} . Since the square root of 4 is 2, youâ€™d solve 2/2=1. This is your cosine.

steps.title: Get the sine coordinate of an angle by counting the fingers to the right.
steps.content: Get the sine coordinate of an angle by counting the fingers to the right. Put your finger down again, then count the number of fingers to the right. Take the square root of this number, then divide it by 2. [15] X Research source In the example above, youâ€™d see that for a 30 degree angle you only have one finger to the right, your pinky finger. That means your sine coordinate would be 1 2 {\displaystyle {\frac {\sqrt {1}}{2}}} . Since the square root of 1 is 1, you can just write 1/2. For your 0 degree angle, youâ€™d see that there are no fingers to the right of your pinky. This means your sine must be 0.

steps.title: Switch the charge on your coordinates to represent other quadrants.
steps.content: Switch the charge on your coordinates to represent other quadrants. Each quadrant has its own different positive or negative charge. Itâ€™s easiest to see this charge when you look at the circle on a grid. The first quadrant is between the positive x-axis and positive y-axis, so both coordinates are positive. The second quadrant is between the positive y-axis and negative x-axis, so it will be negative, positive. Hereâ€™s how each coordinate is charged in each quadrant: [16] X Research source Quadrant 1 coordinates are (+,+). Quadrant 2 coordinates are (-,+). Quadrant 3 coordinates are (-,-). Quadrant 4 coordinates are (+,-).

steps.title: Fill in your unit circle using your hand trick.
steps.content: Fill in your unit circle using your hand trick. You can use the hand trick to fill in the coordinates for each quadrant, even though the angles are different. Just remember to switch up the positive or negative charges depending on the quadrant youâ€™re doing. [17] X Research source

steps.content: Sing a unit circle song. Putting information to a melody is a great way to help you remember it. steps.content: Use flash cards if you prefer to memorize facts. You can make your own flashcards or find pre-made flashcards online.
